C++ code ...    return result; }  [[cpp11::register]] [R data type] my_function_r_([R data type] a,                                                  [R data type] b) {   [C++ data type] A = as_[C++ data type](a);   [C++ data type] B = as_[C++ data type](b);    [C++ data type] result = my_function_(A, B);    return as_[R data type](result); } #include <cpp11.hpp> #include <cpp11armadillo.hpp> #include <unordered_map>  using namespace arma; using namespace cpp11;  Mat<double> ols_(const Mat<double>& Y, const Mat<double>& X);

title: Chapter 3. The Algebra of Least Squares
text: C++ code OLS estimator follows: function must exposed documented can used end-user: Every time need test new function changes function, run devtools::load_all() load new function changes R environment. use function, required create model matrix response vector:
code: Mat<double> ols_(const Mat<double>& Y, const Mat<double>& X) {   Mat<double> XtX = X.t() * X;             // X'X   Mat<double> XtX_inv = inv(XtX);          // (X'X)^(-1)   Mat<double> beta = XtX_inv * X.t() * Y;  // (X'X)^(-1)(X'Y)    return beta; }  [[cpp11::register]] doubles_matrix<> ols_r_(const doubles_matrix<>& y,                                             const doubles_matrix<>& x) {   Mat<double> Y = as_Mat(y);  // Col<double> Y = as_Col(y); also works   Mat<double> X = as_Mat(x);   Mat<double> beta = ols_(Y, X);   return as_doubles_matrix(beta); } #' OLS estimation #' @param y dependent variable #' @param x independent variables #' @return matrix of OLS estimates #' @export ols <- function(y, x) {   ols_r_(y, x) } y <- as.matrix(log(dat1$earnings / (dat1$hours * dat1$week))) X <- cbind(1, dat1$education_num) ols(y, X) #>           [,1] #> [1,] 0.6978150 #> [2,] 0.1550389

title: Chapter 3. The Algebra of Least Squares
text: influence function can written C++ practice, good idea separate residuals leverage keep code modular: function also needs exposed documented: now, assumed functions need exposed documented end-user use .
code: double influence_(const doubles_matrix<>& y, const doubles_matrix<>& x) {   Mat<double> Y = as_Mat(y);   Mat<double> X = as_Mat(x);    Mat<double> e = Y - (X * ols_(Y, X));   Mat<double> XXi = inv(X.t() * X);   Mat<double> leverage = sum(X % (X * XXi), 1);   Mat<double> ones = Mat<double>(Y.n_rows, 1, fill::ones);   Mat<double> d = (leverage % e) / (ones - leverage);    return as_scalar(max(abs(d))); }  [[cpp11::register]] double influence_r_(const doubles_matrix<>& y,                                         const doubles_matrix<>& x) {   return influence_(y, x); } #' Influence function #' @inheritParams ols #' @return numerical value of influence function #' @export influence <- function(y, x) {   influence_r_(y, x) } max(abs(influence(y, x))) #> [1] 0.2926396

text: process data following code:
code: library(hansen) #>  #> Attaching package: 'hansen' #> The following object is masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     influence  experience <- cps09mar$age - cps09mar$education_num - 6 mbf <- (cps09mar$race_num == 2) & (cps09mar$marital_num <= 2) &   (cps09mar$female_num == 1) & (experience == 12) sam <- (cps09mar$race_num == 4) & (cps09mar$marital_num == 7) &   (cps09mar$female_num == 0) dat1 <- cps09mar[mbf, ] dat2 <- cps09mar[sam, ]  dim(dat1) #> [1] 20 18 dim(dat2) #> [1] 268  18

title: Chapter 4. Least Squares Regression
text: Using OLS functions Chapter 3, can compute standard errors following C++ code: Now function can used R:
code: Mat<double> ols2_(const doubles_matrix<>& y, const doubles_matrix<>& x) {   Mat<double> Y = as_Mat(y);   Mat<double> X = as_Mat(x);    Mat<double> beta = ols_(Y, X);   Mat<double> e = Y - (X * beta);   Mat<double> XXi = inv(X.t() * X);   Mat<double> leverage = sum(X % (X * XXi), 1);    double n = Y.n_rows; // using int then returns the wrong "a" value   double k = X.n_cols;   double sig2 = as_scalar((e.t() * e) / (n - k));    Mat<double> ones = Mat<double>(1, k, fill::ones);   Mat<double> xx = inv(X.t() * X);    // Heteroskedastic formula   Mat<double> v0 = xx * sig2;   Mat<double> s0 = sqrt(v0.diag());    // White formula   Mat<double> u1 = X % (e * ones);   Mat<double> v1 = xx * (u1.t() * u1) * xx;   Mat<double> s1 = sqrt(v1.diag());    // HC1 formula   double a = n / (n - k);   Mat<double> v1a = a * (xx * (u1.t() * u1) * xx);   Mat<double> s1a = sqrt(v1a.diag());    // HC2 formula   Mat<double> u2 = X % ((e / sqrt(1 - leverage)) * ones);   Mat<double> v2 = xx * (u2.t() * u2) * xx;   Mat<double> s2 = sqrt(v2.diag());    // HC3 formula   Mat<double> u3 = X % ((e / (1 - leverage)) * ones);   Mat<double> v3 = xx * (u3.t() * u3) * xx;   Mat<double> s3 = sqrt(v3.diag());    // Bind the results   Mat<double> result = join_rows(s0, s1, s1a, s2);   result = join_rows(result, s3); // join_rows admits max 4 arguments   return result.t(); }  [[cpp11::register]] doubles_matrix<> ols2_r_(const doubles_matrix<>& y,                                              const doubles_matrix<>& x) {   return as_doubles_matrix(ols2(y, x)); } y <- as.matrix(log(dat1$earnings / (dat1$hours * dat1$week))) x <- cbind(1, dat1$education_num)  table41 <- ols2(y, x)  rownames(table41) <- c(   "Homoskedastic (4.32)", "HC0 (4.33)", "HC1 (4.34)",   "HC2 (4.35)", "HC3 (4.36)" ) colnames(table41) <- c("Intercept", "Education")  round(table41, 3) #>                      Intercept Education #> Homoskedastic (4.32)     0.707     0.045 #> HC0 (4.33)               0.461     0.029 #> HC1 (4.34)               0.486     0.030 #> HC2 (4.35)               0.493     0.031 #> HC3 (4.36)               0.527     0.033

title: Chapter 4. Least Squares Regression
text: Similar first section, need create subtables: C++ function Table 4.2 similar previous one: Now can replicate results R:
code: edu12 <- (cps09mar$education_num > 11) dat3 <- cps09mar[edu12, ]  marriedF <- (dat3$marital_num <= 3) & (dat3$female_num == 1) marriedM <- (dat3$marital_num <= 3) & (dat3$female_num == 0) unionF <- (dat3$union == 1) & (dat3$female_num == 1) unionM <- (dat3$union == 1) & (dat3$female_num == 0) fmarriedF <- (dat3$marital_num <= 6) & (dat3$marital_num > 3) &   (dat3$female_num == 1) fmarriedM <- (dat3$marital_num <= 6) & (dat3$marital_num > 3) &   (dat3$female_num == 0) black <- (dat3$race_num == 2) american_indian <- (dat3$race_num == 3) asian <- (dat3$race_num == 4) mixed <- (dat3$race_num >= 6) Mat<double> cls_(const doubles_matrix<>& y, const doubles_matrix<>& x) {   Mat<double> Y = as_Mat(y);   Mat<double> X = as_Mat(x);    Mat<double> beta = ols_(Y, X);   Mat<double> e = Y - (X * beta);   Mat<double> XXi = inv(X.t() * X);   Mat<double> leverage = sum(X % (X * XXi), 1);    double n = Y.n_rows;  // using int then returns the wrong "a" value   double k = X.n_cols;    Mat<double> ones = Mat<double>(1, k, fill::ones);   Mat<double> xx = inv(X.t() * X);    // HC2 formula   Mat<double> u2 = X % ((e / sqrt(1 - leverage)) * ones);   Mat<double> v2 = xx * (u2.t() * u2) * xx;   Mat<double> s2 = sqrt(v2.diag());    // Bind the results   Mat<double> result = join_rows(beta, s2);   return result; }  [[cpp11::register]] doubles_matrix<> cls_r_(const doubles_matrix<>& y,                                             const doubles_matrix<>& x) {   return as_doubles_matrix(cls_(y, x)); } y <- as.matrix(log(dat3$earnings / (dat3$hours * dat3$week))) experience <- dat3$age - dat3$education_num - 6 exp2 <- (experience^2) / 100 x <- cbind(   1, dat3$education_num, experience, exp2, dat3$female_num,   unionF, unionM, marriedF, marriedM, fmarriedF, fmarriedM,   dat3$hisp_num, black, american_indian, asian, mixed )  table42 <- cls(y, x)  rownames(table42) <- c(   "Intercept", "Education", "Experience",   "Experience^2 / 100", "Female", "Female union member", "Male union member",   "Married female", "Married male", "Formerly married female",   "Formerly married male", "Hispanic", "Black", "American Indian", "Asian",   "Mixed race" ) colnames(table42) <- c("Estimate", "Std. Error")  round(table42, 3) #>                         Estimate Std. Error #> Intercept                  0.909      0.021 #> Education                  0.117      0.001 #> Experience                 0.033      0.001 #> Experience^2 / 100        -0.056      0.002 #> Female                    -0.098      0.011 #> Female union member        0.023      0.020 #> Male union member          0.095      0.020 #> Married female             0.016      0.010 #> Married male               0.211      0.010 #> Formerly married female   -0.006      0.012 #> Formerly married male      0.083      0.015 #> Hispanic                  -0.108      0.008 #> Black                     -0.096      0.008 #> American Indian           -0.137      0.026 #> Asian                     -0.038      0.013 #> Mixed race                -0.041      0.021

title: Chapter 4. Least Squares Regression
text: C++ code DDK (2011) cluster-robust standard errors follows: Now can use function R:
code: Mat<double> ddk_(const doubles_matrix<>& y,                  const doubles_matrix<>& x,                  const doubles_matrix<>& z) {   Mat<double> Y = as_Mat(y);   Mat<double> X = as_Mat(x);   Mat<double> Z = as_Mat(z);    int n = Y.n_rows;   int k = X.n_cols;    Mat<double> xx = X.t() * X;   Mat<double> xx_inv = inv(xx);   Mat<double> beta = ols_(Y, X);      Mat<double> xe(n, k);   for (int j = 0; j < k; j++) {     xe.col(j) = X.col(j) % (Y - X * beta);   }    // Unique groups in Z   Mat<double> Z_unique = unique(Z);   int n_groups = Z_unique.n_rows;    // Grouped sums   Mat<double> xe_sum(n_groups, k, fill::zeros);   for (int g = 0; g < n_groups; g++) {     int group = Z_unique(g, 0);     for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {       if (Z(i, 0) == group) {         xe_sum.row(g) += xe.row(i);       }     }   }    Mat<double> omega = xe_sum.t() * xe_sum;   double scale = (n_groups / (n_groups - 1)) * ((n - 1) / (n - k));   Mat<double> V_clustered = scale * (xx_inv * omega * xx_inv);   Mat<double> se_clustered = sqrt(V_clustered.diag());    return join_rows(beta, se_clustered); }  [[cpp11::register]] doubles_matrix<> ddk_r_(const doubles_matrix<>& y,                                             const doubles_matrix<>& x,                                             const doubles_matrix<>& z) {   return as_doubles_matrix(ddk(y, x, z)); } y <- scale(as.matrix(ddk2011$totalscore)) x <- cbind(1, as.matrix(ddk2011$tracking_num)) z <- as.matrix(ddk2011$schoolid)  # if we do not change the storage type of x and z, the function will not work # and will return an integer vs double error  storage.mode(x) <- "double" storage.mode(z) <- "double"  ddk <- ddk(y, x, z) rownames(ddk) <- c("Intercept", "Tracking") colnames(ddk) <- c("Estimate", "Std. Error")  round(ddk, 3) #>           Estimate Std. Error #> Intercept   -0.071      0.054 #> Tracking     0.138      0.077

title: Chapter 8. Restricted Estimation
text: Using OLS functions Chapter 4, can compute slopes standard errors following C++ code: Now can use function R: Now create new function constrained regression C++: Now can use function R: Now create new function efficient minimum distance regression C++: Now can use function R: Putting results together:
code: Mat<double> ols3_(const doubles_matrix<>& y, const doubles_matrix<>& x) {   Mat<double> Y = as_Mat(y);   Mat<double> X = as_Mat(x);    int n = x.nrow();   int k = x.ncol();    Mat<double> beta_ols = ols_(Y, X);   Mat<double> e_ols = Y - (X * beta_ols);   Mat<double> Xe_ols = X.each_col() % e_ols;   Mat<double> invX = inv(X.t() * X);   Mat<double> V_ols = (n / (n - k)) * invX * (Xe_ols.t() * Xe_ols) * invX;   Mat<double> se_ols = sqrt(V_ols.diag());    Mat<double> res = join_rows(beta_ols, se_ols);   return res; }  [[cpp11::register]] doubles_matrix<> ols3_r_(const doubles_matrix<>& y,                                              const doubles_matrix<>& x) {   return as_doubles_matrix(ols3_(y, x)); } table81_1 <- ols3(y, x)  rownames(table81_1) <- c(   "Intercept", "log(GDP 1960)", "log(1/GDP)",   "log(n+g+delta)", "log(School)" ) colnames(table81_1) <- c("Estimate", "Std. Error")  round(table81_1, 3) #>                Estimate Std. Error #> Intercept         3.022      0.718 #> log(GDP 1960)    -0.288      0.053 #> log(1/GDP)        0.524      0.105 #> log(n+g+delta)   -0.506      0.230 #> log(School)       0.231      0.065 Mat<double> cns_(const doubles_matrix<>& y, const doubles_matrix<>& x,                  const doubles_matrix<>& r) {   Mat<double> Y = as_Mat(y);   Mat<double> X = as_Mat(x);   Mat<double> R = as_Mat(r);    int n = x.nrow();   int k = x.ncol();    Mat<double> invX = inv(X.t() * X);   Mat<double> iR = invX * R * inv(R.t() * invX * R) * R.t();   Mat<double> beta_ols = ols_(Y, X);   Mat<double> beta_cns = beta_ols - (iR * beta_ols);   Mat<double> e_cns = Y - (X * beta_cns);   Mat<double> Xe_cns = X.each_col() % e_cns;   Mat<double> V_tilde = (n / (n - k + 1)) * invX * (Xe_cns.t() * Xe_cns) * invX;   Mat<double> V_cls = V_tilde - (iR * V_tilde) - (V_tilde * iR.t()) +     (iR * V_tilde * iR.t());   Mat<double> se_cns = sqrt(V_cls.diag());    Mat<double> res = join_rows(beta_cns, se_cns);   return res; }  [[cpp11::register]] doubles_matrix<> cns_r_(const doubles_matrix<>& y,                                             const doubles_matrix<>& x,                                             const doubles_matrix<>& r) {   return as_doubles_matrix(cns_(y, x, r)); } r <- as.matrix(c(0, 0, 1, 1, 1))  table81_2 <- cns(y, x, r)  rownames(table81_2) <- rownames(table81_1) colnames(table81_2) <- colnames(table81_1)  round(table81_2, 3) #>                Estimate Std. Error #> Intercept         2.457      0.430 #> log(GDP 1960)    -0.298      0.052 #> log(1/GDP)        0.501      0.090 #> log(n+g+delta)   -0.736      0.076 #> log(School)       0.235      0.064 Mat<double> emd_(const doubles_matrix<>& y, const doubles_matrix<>& x,                  const doubles_matrix<>& r) {   Mat<double> Y = as_Mat(y);   Mat<double> X = as_Mat(x);   Mat<double> R = as_Mat(r);    int n = x.nrow();   int k = x.ncol();    Mat<double> invX = inv(X.t() * X);   Mat<double> beta_ols = ols_(Y, X);   Mat<double> e_ols = Y - (X * beta_ols);   Mat<double> Xe_ols = X.each_col() % e_ols;   Mat<double> V_ols = (n / (n - k)) * invX * (Xe_ols.t() * Xe_ols) * invX;    Mat<double> V_r = V_ols * R * inv(R.t() * V_ols * R) * R.t();   Mat<double> beta_emd = beta_ols - V_r * beta_ols;   Mat<double> e_emd = Y - (X * beta_emd);   Mat<double> Xe_emd = X.each_col() % e_emd;    Mat<double> V2 = (n / (n - k + 1)) * invX * (Xe_emd.t() * Xe_emd) * invX;   Mat<double> V_emd = V2 - V2 * R * inv(R.t() * V2 * R) * R.t() * V2;   Mat<double> se_emd = sqrt(V_emd.diag());    Mat<double> res = join_rows(beta_emd, se_emd);   return res; }  [[cpp11::register]] doubles_matrix<> emd_r_(const doubles_matrix<>& y,                                             const doubles_matrix<>& x,                                             const doubles_matrix<>& r) {   return as_doubles_matrix(emd_(y, x, r)); } table81_3 <- emd(y, x, r)  rownames(table81_3) <- rownames(table81_1) colnames(table81_3) <- colnames(table81_1)  round(table81_3, 3) #>                Estimate Std. Error #> Intercept         2.481      0.435 #> log(GDP 1960)    -0.297      0.052 #> log(1/GDP)        0.462      0.079 #> log(n+g+delta)   -0.711      0.071 #> log(School)       0.249      0.063 table81 <- cbind(   paste0(     round(table81_1[, "Estimate"], 3), " (",     round(table81_1[, "Std. Error"], 3), ")"   ),   paste0(     round(table81_2[, "Estimate"], 3), " (",     round(table81_2[, "Std. Error"], 3), ")"   ),   paste0(     round(table81_3[, "Estimate"], 3), " (",     round(table81_3[, "Std. Error"], 3), ")"   ) )  rownames(table81) <- rownames(table81_1) colnames(table81) <- c("OLS", "CNS", "EMD")

Companies changed date accounting year end days excluded, data refer 12 month periods. also excluded companies either employment one constructed measures real wages, real capital, real inventories real sales jumped factor 3 one year next. filter remove companies data recorded erroneously companies experienced major mergers. Finally, restricted attention companies allocate one 9 broad sub-sectors manufacturing industry using Datastream's breakdown total sales product available 1980 onwards.

title: hansen: Datasets and Unofficial Solutions from 'Econometrics' by Bruce E. Hansen — hansen-package
text: package provides datasets book 'Econometrics' Bruce E. Hansen <isbn:9780691235899> along unofficial refactored code using 'cpp11armadillo' show 'cpp11armadillo' usage. original datasets adapted multiple sources, including: Arellano Bond (1991) doi:10.2307/2297968 ; Acemoglu, Johnson, Robinson (2001) doi:10.1257/aer.91.5.1369 ; Angrist Krueger (1991) doi:10.2307/2937954 ; Angrist Lavy (1999) doi:10.1162/003355399556061 ; Bernheim, Meer Novarro doi:10.1257/pol.20130351 ; Bureau Labor Statistics; Card (1995) doi:10.3386/w4483 ; Cox, Hansen Jimenez (2004) doi:10.1016/S0047-2727(03)00069-0 ; Card, Mas Rothstein (2008) doi:10.1162/qjec.2008.123.1.177 ; Duflo, Duppas Kremer (2011) doi:10.1257/aer.101.5.1739 ; Di Tella Schargrodsky (2004) doi:10.1257/000282804322970733 ; McCracken Ng (2015) doi:10.20955/wp.2015.012 ; Hall Hall (1993) doi:10.2307/2534602 ; Kilian (2009) doi:10.1257/aer.99.3.1053 ; Koppelman Wen (2000) doi:10.1016/S0191-2615(99)00012-0 ; Wen Koppelman (2001) doi:10.1016/S0191-2615(00)00045-X ; Ludwig Miller (2007) doi:10.1162/qjec.122.1.159 ; Mankiw, Romer Weil (1992) doi:10.2307/2118477 ; Nerlove (1963); Papageorgiou, Saam Schulte (2017) doi:10.7910/DVN/67QCH2 ; Reinhardt Rogoff (2010) doi:10.1257/aer.100.2.573 .

text: Detailed financial metrics U.S. corporations, focusing investment, financial ratios, stock performance. Includes essential economic indicators capture corporate financial health performance year. Data spans multiple years includes various financial metrics essential corporate analysis.

title: Hall and Hall (1993) Dataset Documentation — invest1993
Hall and Hall (1993) Dataset Documentation — invest1993
text: data frame 27,566 observations 23 variables: cusip Committee Uniform Security Identification Procedures (CUSIP) code, identifying firm. first six digits represent firm code number. year year data, represented two-digit value. pstar present discounted value (PDV) dividends anticipated firm's common stock future, discounted risk-free rate plus overall risk premium (approximately 4 percent). z0 first term linearized expression z (outlined Appendix paper). pricef actual price common stock end fiscal year. divf dividends paid fiscal year. rnda Research development (R&D) expenditure assets ratio. adva Advertising expenditure assets ratio. fyr month fiscal year ends, ranging 1 (January) 12 (December). ardsic modified 2.5-digit Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) code, roughly similar used Bound, Cummins, Griliches, Hall, Jaffe (1984) "R&D Patents?" exityr year firm exited sample. inva Investment assets ratio, reflecting proportion investment relative company's total assets. cfa Cash flow assets ratio, indicating cash-generating efficiency assets. debta Long-term debt assets ratio, measure company's financial leverage. sales Annual sales revenue (millions dollars). netcap adjusted book value assets, accounting plant, property, equipment, inventories, components, inflation adjustments per Brainard, Shoven, Weiss's approach. earnsh Reported earnings per share (EPS). nyseamex Indicator variable set 1 firm listed New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) American Stock Exchange (AMEX), otherwise 0. h0 Instrumental variable specified equation B-5 referenced paper. h1 Another instrumental variable specified equation B-5 referenced paper. vala Total market value assets ratio, often referred Tobin's Q. oneper One-period rate return, adjusted non-diversifiable discounting. sharef Shares common stock outstanding, represented thousands.

title: Hall and Hall (1993) Dataset Documentation — invest1993
text: Bronwyn H. Hall Robert E. Hall, "Value Performance U.S. Corporations," Brookings Papers Economic Activity, 1993 (1), 1-50. Data sourced https://eml.berkeley.edu/~bhhall/bhdata.html.

title: Hall and Hall (1993) Dataset Documentation — invest1993
text: values nominal millions dollars unless stated otherwise. Stock values end--year.

title: Kilian (2009) Oil Market Dataset — kilian2009
text: Monthly observations February 1973 December 2007 global oil production, economic activity, real crude oil prices.

title: Kilian (2009) Oil Market Dataset — kilian2009
Kilian (2009) Oil Market Dataset — kilian2009
text: data frame 3 observations 4 variables: time Time index monthly format (e.g., 1973m2 February 1973) oil Percentage change global oil production. Calculated log difference world crude oil production (millions barrels per day, monthly average). Source: U.S. Department Energy. output Global real economic activity index, derived single-voyage ocean freight rates dry cargo. Index logs normalized. price Real price crude oil, based refiner acquisition cost imported crude oil, deflated U.S. CPI. Data source: U.S. Department Energy.

title: Kilian (2009) Oil Market Dataset — kilian2009
text: Kilian, Lutz. 2009. "Oil Price Shocks Alike: Disentangling Demand Supply Shocks Crude Oil Market." American Economic Review, 1053-1069. Data available https://www.openicpsr.org/openicpsr/project/113299/version/V1/view

title: Kilian (2009) Oil Market Dataset — kilian2009
text: dataset provides monthly indices help analyze effects various oil price shocks, specific distinctions demand supply drivers oil market.

what: Koppelman, Forinash and Wen ModeCanada Data — koppelman
title: Koppelman, Forinash and Wen ModeCanada Data — koppelman
text: subset ModeCanada, initially developed VIA Rail 1989 estimate demand high-speed rail Toronto-Montreal corridor. Collected part Passenger Review business travelers, dataset includes information mode choice trip characteristics, focusing choices among train, air, bus, car options. dataset balanced include cases four travel modes recorded.

title: Koppelman, Forinash and Wen ModeCanada Data — koppelman
Koppelman, Forinash and Wen ModeCanada Data — koppelman
text: data frame 11,116 observations 2,779 individual cases (travelers) following variables: case Unique identifier individual traveler. alternative Mode transportation chosen traveler: Train, Air, Bus, Car. choice Selected mode indicator variable. distance Total trip distance kilometers. variable case-specific. cost Trip cost Canadian dollars (CAD). variable varies case alternative. intime -vehicle travel time minutes. variable varies case alternative. outtime --vehicle travel time minutes. variable varies case alternative. income Household income traveler, recorded categories. variable case-specific. urban Large city indicator variable (case-specific).

title: Koppelman, Forinash and Wen ModeCanada Data — koppelman
text: Forinash, C. V., & Koppelman, F. S. (1993). "Application interpretation nested logit models intercity mode choice." Transportation Research Record, 1413, 98-106. Koppelman, F. S., & Wen, C. H. (2000). "paired combinatorial logit model: properties, estimation, application." Transportation Research Part B, 34, 75-89. Wen, C. H., & Koppelman, F. S. (2001). "generalized nested logit model." Transportation Research Part B, 35, 627-641.

title: Koppelman, Forinash and Wen ModeCanada Data — koppelman
text: dataset allows analysis intercity mode choices based traveler trip characteristics, enabling insights factors influencing selection train, air, bus, car travel. abridged version included mlogit R package used several transportation research papers modeling estimation choice preferences.

title: Ludwig and Miller (2007) Impact of Head Start Program on Children's Life Chances — lm2007
text: Ludwig, J., & Miller, D. L. (2007). "Head Start improve children's life chances? Evidence regression discontinuity design," Quarterly Journal Economics 122(1), 159-1208. Matias D. title: Ludwig and Miller (2007) Impact of Head Start Program on Children's Life Chances — lm2007
